Breadth-First.Explanation: Generates multiple street-name hypotheses (Schillerplatz, Boppstraße, Münsterplatz) and explores broadly without yet verifying a single option.

Depth-First.Explanation: Verifies specific clues pointing to Mainz as the city.
Depth-First.KeyElement: Johannes Gutenberg sign, red flags with wheel, Baroque sandstone building

Depth-First.Explanation: Analyzes license plates and transit signage to confirm Mainz and suggest a neighborhood.
Depth-First.KeyElement: License plate “MZ”, bus line 9 for Bretzenheim

Depth-First.Explanation: Focuses on identifying the exact street by recalling and comparing known road names.
Examines transport modes and district boundaries to narrow the neighborhood within Mainz.
Depth-First.KeyElement: Bus line 9, absence of trams, Rheinallee border between Altstadt/Neustadt

Depth-First.Explanation: Uses approach direction and landmark positions to confirm Altstadt location.
Depth-First.KeyElement: Sign on B9 from Wiesbaden, Theodor Heuss Bridge, Electoral Palace position

Depth-First.Explanation: Compares sign style to distinguish between a plaza sign and a city-entry marker.
Depth-First.KeyElement: Civic marker style vs. plaza-located signage

Depth-First.Explanation: Pinpoints the entry sign’s location on B9 Rheinallee by combining route and landmark data.
Depth-First.KeyElement: Entry sign on Rheinallee near Electoral Palace

Depth-First.Explanation: Employs Wikipedia citations to validate neighborhood and vehicle-registration clues.
Aggregates and systematically evaluates all numbered clues to reach a final precise location.
Depth-First.KeyElement: Five key clues with sources (welcome sign, palace façade, “MZ” plates, road layout, orientation)

Breadth-Depth Switch.Explanation: After detailed verification of Mainz clues, the analysis broadens to consider multiple street-name possibilities.
Having generated several street hypotheses, the model narrows focus to verify specific street identities.
